cluster_relations.rel_desc: Sports have a significant economic impact that contributes to broader culture, society, and implicitly the global economy.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ImpactScope: broad cultural and societal economic effects

remarks: Relation extrapolates from general economic impact wording to the global economy context described later in the same chunk.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Major sporting events generate significant revenue for host cities.
Major sporting events generate significant revenue for host countries.
Major sporting events stimulate local economies around host locations.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: during and following major sporting events
qualifiers.CausalHint: creating jobs, boosting tourism, and stimulating

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The sports industry has become a major player in the global economy.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scale: billions of dollars of spending annually

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Spending on sports-related products and services contributes significant revenue to the sports industry.
remarks: Direction chosen from products/services to industry to represent revenue inflow.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Spending on sports-related products and services contributes to activity in the global economy.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: FlowType: global spending on sports-related goods and services

remarks: Relation added to capture macroeconomic context implied by the description.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject has a measurable economic impact on the object, such as influencing growth, activity, or overall economic conditions.
args.justification: Both relations describe broad economic effects (not just revenue) that sports or sports-related spending have on the global economy, matching a general economic impact predicate rather than a narrower revenue or role concept.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject generates or contributes monetary revenue for the object.
args.justification: All three relations describe the subject as a source of revenue for the object (host cities, host countries, or the sports industry) using similar wording about generating or contributing revenue.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject stimulates or boosts economic activity within the object region or economy.
args.justification: This relation specifically highlights that major sporting events stimulate local economies (jobs, tourism, activity) rather than simply being a generic impact or revenue flow, so a dedicated predicate for stimulating economic activity is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject constitutes a major component or significant sector within the object system.
args.justification: The text states that the sports industry has become a major player in the global economy, which is best modeled as the industry being a major component/sector of the global economy rather than a generic impact or revenue relation.

All these relations describe ways in which sports, sporting events, or sports-related products affect economic systems (global economy, local economies, host locations, or the sports industry itself) through impact, revenue generation, or economic role, so they belong to a shared economic impact relation class.

Each relation encodes a causal or contributory effect (sports and related activities causing economic changes such as revenue, growth, or major economic roles), which fits the broad CAUSALITY dimension.
